claim: If you dream of doing something, making a wish when you dream does not guarantee success.

supporting.text: Dreams are a product of subconscious activity and do not have the power to influence real-world outcomes.

attacks.text: Dreams are a product of subconscious activity and do not have the power to influence real-world outcomes.
Some studies suggest that visualization in dreams can enhance motivation and indirectly improve real-world performance.
The placebo effect demonstrates that belief alone can sometimes influence outcomes, suggesting dreams might have indirect power.
The placebo effect is context-dependent and unreliable for significant real-world changes, limiting its relevance to dream influence.

supporting.text: Success is determined by actions and efforts in waking life, not by wishes made during dreams.

attacks.text: Success is determined by actions and efforts in waking life, not by wishes made during dreams.
Some psychological studies suggest that visualizing success (including in dreams) can positively influence motivation and subsequent actions.
The placebo effect demonstrates that belief alone can sometimes lead to measurable success, even if the belief originates from a dream or wish.
Many successful individuals attribute part of their achievements to intuitive insights or creative breakthroughs that occurred during dreaming states.
Correlation does not imply causation; such anecdotes may be post-hoc rationalizations rather than evidence of dreams directly causing success.

supporting.text: There is no scientific evidence that wishing in dreams has any causal effect on achieving goals.

attacks.text: There is no scientific evidence that wishing in dreams has any causal effect on achieving goals.
Anecdotal evidence suggests some people attribute their success to subconscious motivations reinforced by dreams.
Anecdotes are unreliable due to confirmation bias and lack of controlled conditions.
Dreams may indirectly influence behavior by shaping mindset or motivation, which can affect outcomes.
Without measurable mechanisms, this remains speculative and lacks empirical validation.

supporting.text: Dreams are often symbolic or random and do not reflect actionable intentions or guarantees.

attacks.text: Dreams are often symbolic or random and do not reflect actionable intentions or guarantees.
Some cultures and psychological studies suggest that dreams can reflect subconscious desires, which may influence real-world actions and outcomes.
Even if dreams reflect subconscious desires, there is no empirical evidence that acting on them guarantees success.
Lucid dreaming allows individuals to consciously control their dreams, potentially turning wishes into actionable plans.
Lucid dreaming is rare and difficult to achieve consistently, making it an unreliable method for guaranteeing success.

supporting.text: Psychological studies show that motivation and planning, not dream content, are key predictors of success.

attacks.text: Psychological studies show that motivation and planning, not dream content, are key predictors of success.
Dream content can influence subconscious motivation, which indirectly affects planning and execution.
Empirical studies on goal-setting show that explicit visualization (including dreams) correlates with higher achievement rates.
Many successful individuals report no recollection of dreams or dismiss them as irrelevant to their achievements.
Confirmation bias may skew such self-reports, as people tend to attribute success to conscious effort rather than subconscious factors.
